div1.p:
FIELD NOTES #10 - Abstracts of Articles
Dealing With the Destruction of Certain
Aquatic Plants.

Through the courtesy of the Bureau of Fisheries, two articles
dealing with the destruction of certain aquatic plants have been brought
to the attention of this office. These articles are abstracted for the
information of field directors engaged in malaria control.

Mr. H. L. Canfield, Superintendent of fish culture at the
Fairport fisheries station, has found the following method very
successful in destroying cat-tails in ponds which must be main-
tained: Drain the pond, mow the cat-tails as low as practicable,
and plow or dig a ditch below the water line sufficiently deep to
sever the cat-tail roots and disconnect them from the land side.
This ditch should completely surround the patch of cat-tails, as
its purpose is to entirely cut off the air supply to the cat-tail
roots from the land side. Immediately flood the pond and maintain
the water level over all the stubble continuously for a week or ten
days and the cat-tails will die for want of oxygen.

Major Earl North of the Engineers Corps, U. S. Army, reports
the destruction of water hyacinths by a solution of white arsenic
(arsenious oxide) and washing soda (Sodium carbonate): The solution
was prepared by taking one pound of white arsenic, one pound of wash-
ing soda and one gallon of water. This was boiled for two hours and
then diluted to make sixteen or twenty gallons depending upon the
strength desired.

For spraying the solution over the hyacinths, a duplex
Worthington pump (size 4 1/2" x 2 3/4") and one-inch steam hose, 6 ply,
with a Fuller nozzle, was used. This nozzle was used for the reason
that it gives a very fine spray, which is desirable to avoid waste
of material. The pressure on the hose is usually fifty pounds.

Upon warm sunshiny days, one gallons of diluted solution is,
ordinarily, sufficient to destroy ten square yards of hyacinths. If
they day is cloudy or cool, a larger quantity is necessary, Where the
hyacinths are very tall, the spray does not reach the shorter plants
and the first application kills only the taller ones. A second ap-
plication then becomes necessary in order to reach those not touched
at first.
